text: okay hi everyone um first off let me just say thank you for coming out to reinvent this year we
appreciate it um and welcome to this talk on building cloudback mobile apps
my name is glenn dierkes i'm a software engineer and i've been with amazon for over 10 years
the majority of that time has been with aws i've been on a a bunch of different service teams for the last few years
i've been with a team called aws mobile and the aws mobile team our goal is to
you know create tools and services that make it easier for mobile developers to build great apps
so what i'm hoping to accomplish in this session is to talk about and demonstrate how
cloud services can help you make great apps and if we think about apps today
you know we see that there's you know there's been an evolution of apps over the you know over the past few years
but but a lot of apps tend to have you know one or some or all of these features
and that includes things like social login you know allowing your your users to to log in with an account that they
already have from a from an identity provider geo-tagging data a lot of devices today
have a gps or some other mechanism by which to get you know the user's location and being able to um
to use that data to give them location relevant information
um file and data storage and then uh push notifications i'm sure
we all have an app that you get you know uh notifications up you know a sports update or something like that
um you know on a continual basis
okay so if we look at aws and we we look at how does it play
within the mobile landscape there's a couple of things a couple of services that specifically address the
features i just talked about now this doesn't represent everything that aws has for mobile this is more of a snapshot and just kind
of a range of different things that we offer and it's specifically more about the things that i'm going to be talking
about today in the talk but there is there is a service called aws iam or identity and access
management and that can enable um social login
amazon s3 or simple storage service that's great for you know file storage
large data storage amazon dynodb is great for for user data
and then amazon sns or simple notification service can help with uh mobile push or push notifications
now one of some of the great things about aws and if you went to the keynote this morning you probably heard some of
these is that it's you know it's a it's a pick and choose you know you don't have to get all of whatever aws
offers you can pick and choose what pieces you want to use so if you just wanted to add
push notifications to your app you can do that by just getting involved with sns mobile push and you can just leave
it at that but if you wanted to do more and you wanted to enable social login you could add that as well so you can
pick and choose what pieces of aws you want to use and what you think will help make your app better
another great thing is that aws is worldwide we have regions you know many continents
and lots of different locations so we can make sure that your data is near to your customers and where you expect them
to be using it another great feature is that a lot of these services
have a free tier so you can you can try essentially risk-free these services out you can try
you know working with it coding against it integrating into your app and within a certain amount of usage
there's there's no cost to you and as as also mentioned this morning you know it's it's pay as you go or it
can be on demand so you only pay for as much as you use if you decide to stop using the service
you don't pay anymore okay
so for this talk what we what we did is we put together a demo app that kind of highlights the different
features i had mentioned earlier and basic it's a it's a pretty simple app but it's it's an app that allows you
users to share geotagged photos with others so first i want to just
just go do a quick demo but throughout the session i'm going to go i'm going to be going back to the app going into a
little bit more detail showing code and showing specifically how we got certain parts of the app to work
so i can do this okay all right so
to start off with i can log in and and i'm prompted with different ways that i can log in so you
can see here i can choose to log in with with my facebook account now i've already
authorized um facebook with this app so now it's logged me in
and so then i can i can view pictures so i have no personal pictures but i do have public pictures
and so i can click to look at a picture and that's a great public picture right there
i can mark pictures let me go back for a second i can mark pictures as favorite
and then i can see my list of favorite pictures i can also add pictures
and then i can also view the pictures of you know when any time somebody uh uploads a picture a geo tags the
location they uploaded the picture from and we can see the different pictures where they are
you know from on the map
so like i said that that's just a brief overview of the app and i'll be showing the different parts
and how they they fit together now one other thing i want to mention is
the app i'm showing is if you haven't noticed already it's it's an ios app but all of the technology and everything
that we have is we have available for android as well so this app could be completely written in android if you
wanted to do that as well
so this is the architecture of the app and how it all kind of fits together
so to start with the client connect you know using a technology called web identity federation can connect with
identity and access management to then connect to and allow the users to log in with facebook or google plus
or log in with amazon we have it enabled with the s3 transfer
manager to be able to talk to amazon s3 and that's for getting the pictures and uploading pictures
to store the favorites we use the aws mobile sdks and we'd store that directly into amazon dynamodb
and then to get the geo information what we did is we have actually a geo server that runs and connects the app connects
to and it uses the geo library for amazon dynamodb to be able to
geotag data and put that data into to dynamodb
so first let's just talk about web identity federation
all right so what i'm going to do is i'm going to walk you through the process by which web identity federation works
so first the mobile client you know the user would press like like i showed you know i pressed on the login button so
the user would press log in and the the mobile client would redirect the user to
to facebook or whatever third party identity provider they chose
and the user would then be asked to authenticate so in some cases to log in with you know
to type in their username and password for facebook or in the case since i had already authenticated
um facebook just said oh yeah i've got his information he's good to go
so at that point the identity provider returns an access token
and so the mobile client can take that access token and can send it to amazon sts which
stands for security token service and that's a service that's part of iam or identity and access management
and what sts is going to do with that token is it's going to go back to the identity provider and validate it to
make sure that there was no tampering you know midstream or anything like that and once it gets that validation
from the identity provider it can then send back
aws temporary credentials back to the mobile client now if you're familiar with aws
you understand why we need to get credentials back to um back to the mobile client
credentials is how you communicate with any of the services that aws offers
so you need those credentials on the device to be able to interact with them
and if you're new to aws that's that's a piece of information that you'll be uh quickly familiar with if you start using
it the credentials allow you to sign requests and then communicate with the various services
and so that tells aws who you are and make sure that we're granting access to the right people to that to the you
know to your resources now the other thing that we can do that sds can do is it comply a policy
to the credentials and what the policy object can do is it can limit exactly what rights those
credentials have so for for example if i only want to give the credentials the right to access s3
i can say that's all he has and i can restrict it further by saying he only has rights to this bucket with an s3
and so you can really restrict exactly what the person can do with those credentials
further with web identity federation you can use what's called
policy variables and so what the policy variables can do is they can take the id that comes from the uh you know
from the user that logged in with the third party uh identity provider and also put that into it dynamically into
the policy so that way that allows you for each user to customize exactly what
rights they have within the within your resources within the policy so what it means you can silo and
segregate your users from each other so you know that one user can't trample upon the data and usage of another user
so once the the credentials are are all set up and on to the client we can now from the mobile client access
aws and so then we can access s3 or dynamodb or whatever whatever services we want
and we need that that mobile client or mobile app to have access to
so so why you know why would we allow um web web identity federation and or why
would somebody want to use it and one of one of the you know most obvious things is that you
know managing user accounts and passwords is not easy you have to set up a database you have to you know store
the passwords uh securely and it's a lot of work and it's it doesn't enhance your app any better i don't think anybody's
going around boy i really love that login or user registration process for the app right you know nobody's excited
about the login process and users are getting tired of having to create another account that they have to manage
and remember a password for so if you can enable allow them to use their existing accounts
it makes the app a little easier to work with and get started with and we support with through web identity federation
some of the major uh identity providers facebook google and amazon and like i mentioned
that the whole process allows you to get temporary and restricted credentials onto the
device one of the things that we don't recommend is actually putting the credentials into your mobile application
code it's got a couple of problems it can be it can be compromised it's not secure
and then worse yet if if for some reason you needed to change your credentials and you needed to rotate your credentials you would actually disable
the app it would be difficult to get an update out there and your users would be locked out for a period of time so using
web identity for iteration you can make the changes at any time on the back end and the users can always get up-to-date
credentials now i i did pretty much a brief overview of web identity federation
but tomorrow a colleague of mine bob kinney he's also on the aws mobile team is going to be doing a session talking
about web identity federation and going into into great depth he's actually going to be showing the same app and
showing how to turn on another identity provider and going through the steps that it takes
to to do that and so that that session is tomorrow at the same time 1 30 to 2 30.
but if you can't get to that if you have another session you want to go to there's a we have a blog post and i'm
going to be talking more about the blog through this session and i'll give you the links for that but there is a blog post that we have
that talks about web identity information and goes into detail about how to set it up and steps you through the process of adding adding it to your
app okay
so next the s3 transfer manager
as the name kind of implies it's it's a vehicle for which to uh communicate and work with um amazon s3
and it provides some higher level functionality now we have as part of the mobile sdks we have like you know the
direct operations that you can do with s3 but this kind of takes it a step further and
tries to make things a little easier especially for a mobile environment
so you know with s3 you want to be able to upload and download data and so you know there's lots of apps
that are doing you know you know uploading pictures videos music or any large content that you can think of you
if you have um if you have a game and you want to upload a new level or something into the app you could use s3 to do that
what the transfer manager is really about is trying to make that very efficient for a mobile environment
you know as the name implies right it's a mobile device people can be walking around meaning that they're going in and out of
connectivity which means that their connection can be lost for a period of time so if you think about
like if some if you have an app that you're trying to get people to upload photos and let's say it's a 100 megabyte photo or a
video and it's 100 megabytes that you're trying to upload and the person's moving around while
he's doing this and he goes in and out of connectivity the transfer could be uh could be broken right and so then he
would have to restart and that's just going to be a pain point for the for the user so what the transfer manager does
is is it actually breaks up the uh the upload into parts and sends up these smaller parts one by
one and so that way you know if it gets through let's say half the parts and then one of the parts fails it only
retries that one part so it's not reloading or trying to retransmit the entire hundred megabytes it's only doing
a portion of it and so then it can get that and then continue on the way and then once it has all the parts done
s3 can automatically put them all together into a single object in the cloud
the same with download let's say another user is trying to download that hundred megabyte video
and the same thing you know let's say the app crashes or something you know he turns off his app accidentally or his phone accidentally during uh during the
download well if you were to restart it traditionally you'd have to restart the entire download process it's going to be
a very painful you know action for the user to go through it especially if you know if it's on wi-fi
it might not be so bad for certain files but if you're on 3g or 4g it's you know it's going to get a little bit more painful
so with the download as well we can we keep track of how much we've downloaded when it restarts we can take
we can you know we can start off from where we left off and continue the download and get the rest of the file
we have some other advanced features like pause resume and cancel that allow you to programmatically you
know pause a a a transfer or resume it later or just cancel it outright
the other thing is that the transfer manager directly connects to s3 so if you have an app let's say that's that
allows people to upload videos if you were to redirect this through your own back end with videos being
larger files you have to keep a connection open for a longer period of time which means you'd have to have if you
have tens of thousands or hundred thousands of users you're going to have to have a big server fleet in which to handle all those connections
instead if you have your app directly connecting to s3 s3 is going to manage all those connections it's going to handle all
that load for you you don't have to have a server back end to to worry about all of that
so let me just uh show a little bit what this looks like
okay so if i wanted to add a picture
so i give it a name i'm gonna i'm gonna make this one private
and up it goes and that was done using the transfer manager
so i go look at my so now you can see that i have that picture now in my uh personal settings
if i wanted to view a picture and this picture is uh is actually quite large it's it's uh
i think it's over 10 megabytes and so you can see it's streaming down
and so i can pause it and so it's it's going to hold there and then if i resume it
it's going to continue from where it left off and so that would be the same if the app had crashed as well if i said hey re you
know start loading this picture again it would start over from where it left off and then if i want to dismiss it
i can dismiss it and that kills that kills the transaction no more network activity going on
oh okay i'm back
so now if you wanted to with our sdks we provide the functionality to implement multi-part
uploads if you wanted to do that this is what a little bit of the code would look like it's actually a little bit more
it needs two helper functions as well and what that code is doing is actually breaking up the file that i wanted to
download into parts sending the parts one by one and then put you know telling s3 to put them all together at the end
now what's not shown here is i took out because i didn't want to take up too many slides i took out the error
handling as well and the other thing is that you wouldn't want to do this on the main thread so
the other part that's not here is doing this in the background you would actually want to do this asynchronously or do it in a background thread and
that's not shown here as well so there's a lot of code there to make
that happen and that's just for upload if you wanted to do download you'd have to do something similar as well
so with the transfer manager it's a little easier to get started so first thing you have to do is you have to create a transfer manager
and you have to give it an s3 client from which to work with an s3 you know we in our client we give you some different settings you can uh
you can change so you give it the s3 client that you want to work with and then if you want to upload a file
that's it you give it the file that you want to upload the bucket name and the key that you want to store it within s3 that's it
this code that line of code behind the scenes is automatically breaking it up into parts sending them one by one doing
all the error handling and doing it in the background the same for download
the same thing this the download doesn't use multi-part upload it uses what's called a feature of s3 called range gets
and so that's doing it in parts and getting that data and if it if it needs to continue can
take it can start from where it left off and again it's a single line of code all the error handling everything
and then if you wanted to pause resume or cancel any of these transfers again it's a single line of code now one thing i would i did i
haven't mentioned is you can you can start multiple transfers in parallel and then you can pause them
all or resume a moral cancel them all with a single line or you can pause or resume individual transfers so one thing
i do when i start an upload i can i can capture the um you know basically the handle to that
upload and then pause that directly i just showed the all case in in this in this fashion and this is code that
actually exists in the app that we we have these these lines of code so you can see in seven lines of code i i could enable
my app to to do uploads downloads pause them whatever with just a few lines of code and it's all in the background
all with error handling so now if you wanted to learn more about
the the transfer manager we have a a number of blog posts on our on our blog that go into detail about different
things how to get it set up how to work with it um and the transfer manager is a part of
our sdks and if you if you wanted to download our sdks they're available on aws.amazon.com
mobile and we have it for both ios and and android
and it's all open source so if you if you wanted to take a look at the transfer manager code you can do that we have our code is available on
github or if you download the sdks you get the code with it so if you want to you know if you wanted to make tweaks or
do things differently you could do that as well if you want to do these something specific to your application you could do that
so next i wanted to talk about the the geo library for amazon dynamodb
and so what the geo library is it's it's actually a java library and it's meant to be used within a a back end or a
middle tier you don't use it directly on the client application and what it does is it produces geo
geohashes that can be used and stored within dynamodb
and one of the reasons that you want to move some of this logic to to a middle tier is
when you do a query for location you know for for geotag data you're going to get a lot of data back and you have to
figure out what's within the the region that you're you're actually trying to query for
and so you want to do that manipulation and a backend because if you do it on a client the client is going to have to send a lot of data back and forth
through through dynamodb and that's going to be taxing and expensive to the to the client user
application so you send you use the library on a backend it can do the communication back and forth with
dynamodb you can then add some additional logic to make sure you filter it for exactly what your needs are
and then send back the smallest amount of data back to the back to the mobile client and just as an
example right i mean if you have an app that's uh you know that has to deal with retail or something like that and you know you can
capture the person's location from their location you can give it a you know like either um
what we call a radius query or a circle or a rectangular query that you can then tell them hey here are stores within
your area relative to your your current position
so let me just walk through it again and so essentially you know the the the mobile client is going to talk to
the geo server and it's going to make a very specific request to either put put geo geotag data in or to get some back
or to to do a query based on on a on a region and so the geo library then has
you know very specific functionality that so it makes this easy you know to get points you know you can call these
methods there's good point put point delete point and then there's two type of queries based on um on a radius we
call it radius it's a circle you give it a center and then you give it a radius or you give it the two endpoints of a rectangle and it looks for all the
points within the database that are within that region it does a bunch of you know
communication back and forth with dynamodb and eventually they figure out what data was it was within that region
then the geo query you can do any additional logic you want to you want to do and send
you know the filter data back to the to the client
so let me just show you that in the app
okay so pretty straightforward so what's
happening here is if you remember the first time i showed this it only had two pins on it now it has a third because i uploaded that third picture
but essentially you know it's it knows our location is las vegas and i'm doing a radius query here of 5000 meters so
it's finding all the points that are within the database that are within that that region that circle
so there's the sorry there's the aws picture that i had
uploaded before so if we look at that
i'll be back so if we look at that code so what's actually happening
and this is code again that you would be running in a server environment the first thing you need to do is you
need to create a dyno db client and with dynodb you want to specify what region you want to work with so for this app we
specified usc 1. then
the main interface is called the geodata manager there's a manager configuration and with it we
give it the dynamodb client that we created and then the table within dynamodb that we want to store or
retrieve our geotag data we then feed that into the geod data
manager now there's there's other configuration that we can do i just went with the default
so now if i wanted to do a query the first thing i'm doing since as i mentioned i did a radius query the first
thing you have to do is you have to give it the the center point and you give it you know you give it the latitude and longitude
and then i specify hey these are the this is these are the data points that i want from the from the database i want
the title of the you know of the picture in this case and the user who uploaded that photo
i put that to all of that together with into a geo radius request and then i just i just send that to the
geodata manager and i have it actually execute the request now at this point it's going to communicate back and forth
with dynamodb to get the points that fall within that region
and so now it's going to return a set of points that that were within that that region that we just queried for
and so at this point we can loop through those points and then for each point i can extract
out the user the user id and title because that's what i told it i wanted to retrieve back by default it will
return back everything to be more efficient i told it to return back the attributes that i wanted
and then at that point i can do extra filtering so in this case what i did is i only allowed a user to um to see the
photos that he actually uploaded that's the matching of the the user id or that the uh the photos that are
marked as public he can you know you can see those photos as well so that allows us to filter the data even further and
then i can return that back and this code actually exists in the server that we have as part of the as part of the
sample so again with the with the geo library
um it's all open source and it's available on github and so if you wanted to customize the
logic and of how the library works or you wanted to make changes you could feel free to do that and we have a blog
series that goes into detail about how the the geo library works talking about the configuration how the the algorithms
actually work to get the geo hashes based on latitude and longitude and how it all breaks up
and on github the sample includes not only the an ios app that's just demonstrating
um doing a you know location-based app it also provides a
middle tier sample tier that you can run in elastic bean stock
so next i wanted to talk about the mobile sdks
and here let me just show you how they're used within the app itself
okay
so if i go to my favorites you can see i have two pictures that i've uh i've marked as favorite
if i go back here i say that i want to add that to the
favorite if i go back it's been added and this is communicating with diana
what do you but it's sending that information to dine would he be
so the way the mobile sdks work is that they provide access directly
from the mobile device to a number of different aws services including binodb s3 sqs sns
and and a few others and so you can access you know those
those services directly from the client and what's one one nice thing about that is if i had this application on two
different devices you can imagine i have this app running on an iphone and then i have an ipad if i were to favorite a
picture on one device and then go look up my favorites on the other device it would be in sync it would be there
automatically because it's it's axing accessing from a single repository the other thing is as i mentioned
earlier with the policy objects dianordibia has something called fine grain access control
so you can specify that a user can only access certain rows of a table so you
can have a single dynamodb table that supports millions or tens of thousands of users
and each user would only be able to see the rows relevant to them
and the sdks are both available for both ios and android
so when you know when using the sdks it's pretty much a consistent pattern if you wanted to use
them so first you create the service client so in this case you know if you wanted to talk to dynamodb you create a
a dynodb client s3 you create an s3 client then you put together your request
you submit the request to the client itself and then that's going to give you results and you would just process that
those you know those data results so if we look at this in actual code
so this is here i'm creating the dynamd client and this is this is the code to actually get the favorites and if you were to look at the code in
the in the sample you would see this code and so then then i put together my get
request so i'm telling it you know i want it for this user id
the data is within a particular dynodb table and i'm telling it to do a consistent
read which means get me the latest data at that point i submitted to the
to the client to dynamodb i submit the request and then it returns back the data at
which point i can pull out the favorites and that's what's being returned
and at the same time you know at the same time you know the same thing is happening for putting uh putting data into dynodb
so since i have the client already i don't need to create that again but i can put i need to put together a put
item request so again i specify the same table i tell it here's here's the user id where i want to store that data for
here's the list of attributes put that all together in the single put item request and submit that to the server
and that's the pattern essentially that's used for for any type of service that you want to work with with
with the sdks and that's the same for android as well android you would follow the same essential process you'd create
a client create a request submit the request and process the results
now on our blog we have a number of different posts that go into different uh different things about the
sdks this the the blog point that i have here actually talks in detail about
dynamodb about using the mobile sdks with dynodb and both sdks are available um including
the code the code is all on on github
so one thing that i can't unfor i can't demonstrate is sns mobile push you can't receive
notifications on a simulator but i just that is we do have that code within the app and i just wanted to talk
about that for a moment so one of the things that sns mobile
push does is it allows you to create you can register devices
individually to receive notifications and you can create a topic and then
subscribe devices to that topic and what that means is you can subscribe to
devices across push notification services so you can subscribe apple devices google devices and android and
amazon devices to a single topic and so when you push to that topic all of those devices would
receive the same notification so you don't have to write separate logic to push to apple devices versus google
devices and so on you can still push individually if you wanted to do that um but this is one nice feature that you
can push across platforms in a single uh in a single publish
the other thing is that the the mobile push console really simplifies setting it up if if
you've done anything with notifications you know you have to get certificates and keys and you have to get that from the actual notification provider you
have to set up the keys and certificates and you have to upload that and set that all up the mobile push console kind of
walks you through that process and simplifies that
so the way it works is the first thing you have to do is you have to create what's called a platform application and this what this does is
it specifies what type of devices that you're going to be uh uh supporting what
what push notification service you're going to support you can set this up programmatically or you can do it through the console that's
what i was talking about before where you give it the keys and the certificates and at the end of the day what you're getting back is you're getting a
platform application arn or amazon resource name
so then when you want to register a device and this is code that we actually have in our client so if if we ask the
uh the app wanted to say hey i guess i'd like to receive notifications
this is the code that would happen it would it would put together what's called a platform endpoint request
and it would specify the the device token string which is going to be specific to the for apple
has its own way android has its own way of doing it but you would get that token string you would put that together with
specific custom data or whatever you want to for the customer and then you would give it the application the
platform application arn you would put that all together in a request and you would submit that to sns
and then that would register the device with that platform application and so then when you publish
that that device would receive notifications and publishing you can do it through the console or you can do it through
programmatically through any one of our sdks and we have a number of sdks that can support
publishing through sns if you wanted to learn more about sns
mobile push jeff barr had a blog post that talks about how you can engage customers and some of the benefits
of the technology as well as the sns mobile push you know documentation has
has a sample app that just shows specifically how to work with sns mobile push
and it walks you through again setting it all up registering a device publishing to that
device and it shows it for the various the you know amazon apple and google
there's also going to be a session on friday where a customer i believe is going to
